SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this discussion this morning. I would like at the outset to express my sincere condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims of both the Monarch and the Seaview Air crashes. No matter how much examination and review we have of the circumstances of both of those crashes, it will not change anything. I am sure everybody in this place joins with me in expressing our heartfelt sympathy and understanding to the families of the victims.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the response by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to Commissioner Staunton's Seaview Air report and, more latterly, to the Plane Safe report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I will elaborate on those a little bit further as I go along.

The Seaview Air report is an exhaustive report. It was a very expensive report. It was spread out over a long period. I think there are explanations for that, and those who are associated with it well understand them. I think they will bring up their priorities again in another place at another time.

On 27 June in this chamber and in the main chamber on 27 June, I expressed my grave concerns about events related to aviation safety in this country, the direction in which the government was heading, and some of the statements being made by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I have expressed those views to him privately. What I am saying now is not something that I have not expressed to him directly or in this place or in the other place on earlier occasions.

The work that was done by the commission of inquiry did pick up the work that was carried out by the inquiry. It was a good example of the two activities working together to minimise expense to the taxpayer and to draw on the information, not duplicating the process that was well under way.

The work that was done by Commissioner Staunton, as I said, is exhaustive. But, looking back through it, the question is what the problem was with the Civil Aviation Authority, as it was then known. More latterly, there has been an attempt to ascribe it to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and—as the reference is in here—to the timidity of the Civil Aviation Authority at the time.

The problems of that timidity and the lack of will in enforcing its responsibilities are rooted in the dramatic and utterly inappropriate change in philosophy and direction of the Civil Aviation Authority brought about by the Chairman, Dick Smith, and the Chief Executive Officer, Frank Baldwin, in 1991. That change in philosophy represented the aviation industry as a customer.

BREAK.PARA: The early report that came forward dealing with the same subject was a coronial inquiry into the Monarch air disaster. I will quote from this document and from a number of other documents in the time I have this morning, just to get these statements together in the one place, on the record, and in the parliament.
In the case of the Monarch, on page 8 of the report the coroner said:

A former chairman of the CAA had advocated a policy of "affordable safety" which favoured a very lenient approach to policing the regulations. "Affordable safety" does not necessarily equate to "necessary safety"; in effect, it was up to each airline to decide if it was affordable to fly safely. If a plane crashes, the airline is up for the cost of the plane; if the passengers and pilots are killed or injured and the airline has no assets or insurance to cover that contingency then the risk is "affordable" to the airline.

The CAA's motto was "a safe and viable industry" but the senior echelons of the CAA placed undue emphasis on promoting a "viable" industry and, as a consequence, were loath to prosecute airlines for breaches of the Regulations or to revoke an AOC and this had the effect on the Airworthiness and Flight Operations Branches which were responsible for policing the Regulations. Internal memos passing between inspectors show they resented the restrictions imposed on them by their superiors . . . The effect of all this was that inspectors were unable to take any action against airlines for breaches of the regulations apart from giving warnings and so‐called counselling.

That is the underpinning. This is where it all began, in that change in philosophy, that change in culture concerning the regulator's role. The primary consideration of the people that are there to ensure that airlines and air services are operated safely was the financial viability of the operator.
Now let me turn to Commissioner Staunton's report. On page 92 of his report, the section dealing with the industry as a customer, pararaph 3.16, it says:
Accompanying these changes were subtle, and not‐so‐subtle, changes of philosophy. The Chairman, Mr Smith, made the following comments in the annual report for 1989‐90:

`The CAA's future is inextricably linked to the future of the aviation industry . . . It follows that what is good for the aviation industry—high safety, lower costs, more aircraft in the air, few delays, more people flying—is also good for the CAA.'

Further, in paragraph 3.17, referring to the review of resources, it says that CAA's core values include being customer orientated. Then we go over to paragraph 3.21. Again, I am quoting directly from Staunton's report on CAA strategies designed to reduce the cost of aviation services to industry, which include:
‐ emphasising the importance of the customer's needs, customer service and the cost of the service we provide.
‐ the need to be more transparent to customers.

It goes on as I move through the report, 3.9, 3.20, then these words of Commissioner Staunton contain a steely message clothed in cotton wool, and I ask members of the parliament to look a little bit more deeply behind what Staunton was really saying. For the sake of propriety, the words are carefully couched, gently. In 3.30 it says:

Mr Dick Smith ceased to be Chairman of the CAA in February 1992. Mr Baldwin resigned as Chief Executive Officer in February 1993. Nonetheless, the concept of the industry as the customer of the CAA remained, at least for some time. In a memorandum that achieved some notoriety, Mr Cannane, then the Airworthiness Manager of the Bankstown District Office, directed his officers in these terms:

`Some of you may think that this was Black Friday at its worst and some may think that what I said was overly harsh and not to your liking . . . Some may question the fact that their jobs, and I include my own, have been threatened if we do not perform our duties in the manner as required by your management. If this comes as a surprise to anyone, then it is time that you got your head out of the clouds.'
Staunton says:
Mr Cannane did not mince words. He said this:
`You are a servant of the industry whether you like it or not. Even when performing your regulative role you are still a servant of the Industry to which you owe your existence.'
And so it goes on in this letter:

`Improve your salesmanship. This means that you will be a servant to our customer, the Industry, that you serve and monitor. They are our customers, service and regulatory, and if we don't have customers then we don't have jobs . . . Anyone acting like a bureaucrat is not performing their duty in a manner acceptable to this management and will not be tolerated.'

These quotes are from a memo sent round from on high, and these are the officers at the coalface trying to ensure that aircraft are airworthy, aircrew are properly qualified and all the things that need to be done to ensure safe air transport are done. Here is the fundamental conflict: that they are our customers—service and regulatory—and that if we do not have customers then we do not have jobs. To me, that is like a policeman going on the street and saying, `Well, if we don't have any burglars, I'm out of a job. We've got to have burglars, otherwise I don't have a job, so we'll catch some but we'll leave others there to keep us all in employment.' It would be ludicrous if it were not so serious.

These are the roots of the problem within the Civil Aviation Authority at that time; that confusion of roles, the contradiction in messages and culture coming down from the board itself. That flowed on to intimidation of staff, and the staff themselves being afraid to carry out their responsibilities. As I move through it, I keep coming back to the problem that the emphasis is upon general aviation, charter operators, recreational flyers, when the reality in this country is that, when we look to the carriage of domestic passengers in 1995‐96 that were carried by the major airlines and the regional airlines, 27.7 million people travelled by air in 1995‐96.

If we take into that the international passengers who arrived in Australian airspace and transited in Australian airports, there are a further 12.1 million people. So, overall, there are 40 million people travelling by air in a year in Australia, and there is no reference in any of this stuff to them. All the noise we hear and all the hoo‐ha we have going on is about the recreational flyers, the weekend warriors. All we hear is whether Mr Smith should be chairman, and whether the board should have somebody on it who has had aviation experience.

I do not want to repeat all of the words that I have used before on this issue. But, I am pleased to see that the minister is now picking up the recommendations, both of Commissioner Staunton and of the Plane Safe report. Undoubtedly, he had a major role in that, along with myself as chair. That was a job that was done to improve safety for everybody. It is a contradiction when the minister in his statement in respect of the Plane Safe report said:
The Australian aviation industry has some of the most professional personnel in the world and they have helped maintain our international standing in aviation safety.

True. But we ought to be concentrating on ensuring that they are performing their task to the required standards of safety and not obsessing ourselves with what happens at the lower end of the market. Most of the activity there is private recreational, self activity, not the 40 million people who use aviation services each year—domestic, regional and international.

So, this incongruent approach where we hear a tremendous amount of noise from the small players and absolute silence from Ansett, Qantas, and the Board of International Airlines—they represent all of the international airlines operating into this country. In this committee this morning, I call upon Ansett, Qantas, the Regional Airlines Association, and the Board of International Airlines representatives to take up their responsibility and to play a more overt and effective role in respect of aviation safety in this country. What we have had is the tip of the tail wagging the dog, and some personality relationships.

You cannot have people going around the aviation industry saying, `Dick Smith is wonderful bloke. He raised $6 million for the government's election campaign.' That is what is on the grapevine. I do not know whether it is true. They are the figures that I have been told. Great bloke. I am not concerned whether he is a great bloke. What I am concerned about are the 40 million people who are entitled to a proper standard of aviation safety when they use the aviation services of this country. It is not good enough for the major carriers to sit mute and have this image peddled across to the Australian public that their interests are not being protected. If they are not being protected, then it is time that Ansett, Qantas, the Board of International Airlines representatives, and the Regional Airlines Association started to speak out and express their concerns and their priorities.

So, the committees that have been formed, the measures that are being implemented now, the random checks on stocks of parts to ensure that bogus parts are not in the system and are not being utilised in aircraft, the random checks in respect of charter operators, are all steps in the right direction. I am appealing to the minister this morning to put aside his obsession with the members of the board and to concentrate on lifting the morale of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority itself. You cannot have confidence and pride in what you do, when your boss is kicking you in the guts all the time anonymously.

The briefing that we had yesterday—and I notice the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Micro‐economic Reform has now joined us—from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority does give one hope and heart for improvement. I thought that it was professional, but it recognises the history of the problems, too, and the fact that they are now pulling together and rebuilding. The principles are under way to work together with those in the industry who accept their safety responsibility. `Who accept their safety responsibility' are the critical words in that. There must be a vigorous pursuit of those who choose not to operate in compliance, and the adoption of a safety system assessment as a base of regulatory approach.

Overall the report is exhaustive. It deals with one tragedy in the history of aviation of this country. Our report from the committee Plane Safe dealt with the general aviation industry as a whole but they complement each other. I am pleased that the report has been concluded. I congratulate Commissioner Staunton and those who worked with him on their efforts in that report and I welcome the response of the government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully and in a very interested frame of mind to the remarks of the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who has great experience in this area. I found his contribution very useful. But I would just remind him of some observations that were made in an editorial in the Canberra Times on 9 June 1996 which I think emphasises that an overall balance has to be struck in looking at this particular matter. The particular editorial says in part:

BREAK.PARA: Perhaps too the blame must rest with those who conceived the so‐called review of resources within the CAA which saw an exodus of some of the organisation's best and brightest. The review of resources will forever stand as an example of how not to trim a corpulent organisation, of retaining too much chaff and too little wheat. Much is made of the fact that Dick Smith was Chairman of the CAA during the review of resources period. It is suggested that Mr Smith's embrace of the notion of affordable safety contributed to laxity which led to the Monarch and Seaview tragedies. Does this make Mr Smith a scapegoat? Probably. Mr Smith cannot walk away from his chairmanship of the CAA blameless but nor should he be pilloried for policies which were endorsed by the government of the day and which clearly were actively pursued by other members of the CAA board.
I commend the whole of that particular editorial to honourable members.

Australia has had an excellent record for air safety and, as has been said by previous speakers, there are a large number of passenger movements in this country—approximately 40 million per year international and domestic. This calls therefore for the highest degree of circumspection and regulation in order that the safety of those people is paramount in the eyes of the regulators of air safety. In other words, well may the standards be kept high. There is an extremely high onus on government to ensure absolute safety and imbue absolute confidence in the travelling public.

Because of the large number of people who are travelling, the large number of movements and its importance on the overall Australian economy, it would seem indeed not so much importance but it is a fact of life that all of us from time to time need to travel. Particularly in commercial and cargo movements, it is almost without question, I would have thought, that we need to ensure the safest airline system, the safest system of managing and assisting aircraft movements that we can possibly have. There really is no argument in my view for trimming air safety. We must have absolute confidence in the safety of our airlines.

It is clear that the inquiry into the Seaview disaster revealed a number of disturbing elements, in particular, the fact that the flight in question was overloaded by something of the order, on one view—the view most favourable to Seaview—of 220 kilograms and, at the other end of scale, 288 kilograms. That is substantial overloading having regard to the size of the aircraft and the number of passengers on board.

The pilot's licence was not valid. There were unsatisfactory work practices adopted by the airline, including understating of hours to avoid fatigue regulations, overstating of hours to inflate pilot experience and to earn the pilot a licence in a different category sooner than he or she would otherwise be able to, and subtle pressure on the employees of the airline to flout regulations, that subtle pressure coming from the management. But even more disturbing, in my view, has been the role of the CAA which, in a sense, reminds me of Mount Erebus revisited.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have had the opportunity to read the book by Mr Justice Mahon who, you might remember, was the commissioner who investigated the Erebus disaster. His report was not accepted by the New Zealand government. Indeed, a monumental exercise in government thuggery occurred at that time in an attempt to try to water down the strong criticism of Air New Zealand by Mr Justice Mahon, and the criticism of the senior bureaucrats from Air New Zealand and other people involved in safety who came before his commission. I wish I could remember his famous phrase describing that evidence—I have used it in court a few times myself. It really emphasised how disturbing it was that these bureaucrats could get together and cover up, and attempt to do a snow job, as they say. And it appears that this has occurred in relation to the CAA here.

There was an attempt—and a successful attempt, it would seem—on the part of some bureaucrats to snow the former board. Indeed, it seems that that may have been carried over to the new board. I was particularly concerned in relation to one of the so‐called whistleblowers, Mr Bob Hoy, who was the district airworthiness manager at Coffs Harbour. He urged suspension of the company's air operators certificate. This occurred in the year of the tragedy, on 13 January 1994. Then on 16 April he went to Canberra to see the then chief executive of the CAA, Mr Doug Roser, to press his concern. Yet these warnings were ignored. Mr Hoy was doing not only what he was paid to do but what was expected of him. He was insisting on standards, on compliance with safety regulations, yet he was perceived by his superiors to be out of step and was subsequently persecuted—hence I say the revisiting of the Erebus situation.

That sort of behaviour is totally unacceptable, in my view, in looking at the question of air safety. We cannot be too diligent. We cannot be too prescriptive. We cannot be too bureaucratic in many respects in regulating air safety because lives are at stake. There are no second chances, as the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) mentioned. In an aircraft crash there are rarely, if ever, survivors. So there are no second chances if there is a slight lapse in regulation.

What concerns me is the attitude of the new board that seems to be exemplified in statements that have been revealed which highlight what I see as the incongruity—and this is a slightly wider issue—of having a judge run a government board. It is really, in my view, inappropriate for judges to be involved in running government appointed boards. Here we have a judge who goes into the media and says in relation to the inquiry of Commissioner Staunton when looking at the report:
It appears that the errors that were made were not errors of expertise.

Having regard to the report itself, that really is quite an absurd statement and unfortunately exposes the judge to criticism which, in my view, tends to undermine the judiciary as a whole. This is a wider issue but, when a judge is in this position, he is placed in this position by the government of the day by being offered an appointment of this nature. Overall, this can tend to bring the administration of justice into disrepute. It is an inappropriate decision in my view to appoint judges to these boards, and it is something that should be discouraged in the future.

But in addition to that, the board itself, in my view, leaves a question mark over the expertise of members of that board. In reality, only one person has relevant aviation experience. With all due respect to the other members of the board, is it really appropriate that people with little or no experience of practical aviation even consider themselves? If they examined their own position before accepting such appointments, should they not really look very carefully at whether or not they feel they should accept positions of this nature?

I know the government have made the offer, and maybe it starts with the government—this was the previous government I am speaking of—but the fact of the matter is it is also something that I would have thought they need to examine themselves. More particularly now that we have had quite trenchant criticism of the board by the minister, and criticism with which I respectfully agree, it is my view that the board really has to take a good hard look at itself.

In conclusion, as far as the operator of this particular airline is concerned, it to me is absolutely on its face inexcusable that when that aircraft disappeared about 1½ hours elapsed before anyone was notified. Having regard to the recommendation for a criminal prosecution of the owner, I think that really is something that might well be taken into account by a court in determining how it should regard the overall operation of that particular airline and the behaviour of its owner in the context of both its slipshod operation and what appears, on its face, an inexcusable delay when the lives of these people were tragically lost.

I too extend my sympathy to the families of those victims. I express the wish that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) maintains the reform process that he has flagged and that we will re‐engender a good degree of confidence in the industry in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my comments on this report this morning, I too would extend my sympathies to the families. It was an incident in Australian aviation history that tore at the heart of all Australians, and one that engenders a lot of trepidation in some of the travelling public in Australia. When people line up to buy a ticket to travel on an aircraft somewhere, whether it be a small aircraft such as that that was involved in this incident or a 747‐400 to travel overseas or a 737 to travel from Canberra to Sydney, there is an unquestionable expectation that the airworthiness of the aircraft being used in that flight has the clear imprimatur of the Commonwealth and of the people that are responsible for safety regulation. The travelling public in this country boards aircraft without giving a second thought to any malfunction that may happen or any incident that may lie ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: As a nation of air travellers in the world today, we are singly very lucky with the low number of accidents such as this. Certainly, this very tragic and apparently avoidable accident has brought to the fore a number of deficiencies that existed in the system at the time. I go back to an inquiry in late 1993 when I was a member of the then Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We were conducting an inquiry into the commercialisation of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority and the ways that had impacted on the services being provided by those two organisations in relation to their direct ownership by the taxpayers of Australia. More importantly, we were examining the safety elements involved in air traffic control and safety surveillance, and surveillance of the regulations that were supposed to be enforced.

You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when the CAA was commercialised, those activities of air traffic control and safety surveillance were all in the one organisation. They were all being run together. We had the opportunity at a public hearing in Sydney of taking evidence from the then Chief Executive Officer, Doug Roser, and the then Director of Safety Regulations, George Marcionis, both of whom appear in this report. They were called to give evidence before this royal commission. From memory, at the public hearing, the evidence that we took from those gentlemen was after the Monarch crash, but before the Seaview crash. I had asked questions at that stage of Marcionis whether he was satisfied that the way the CAA was implementing safety regulations and surveillance was satisfactory. I am sure that if we look in the records from that hearing that the evidence given from him was that it was, that the likes of Monarch would not happen again.

We all know that following the Monarch crash, in a speech that the then shadow minister, the now Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) gave in the House of Representatives, he indicated that he had concerns about the operations of Seaview prior to this incident. In the subsequent report of that inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee, we highlighted the dangers of having a safety regulator commercialised and operating on a commercial basis. The focus could be, and evidently was, too much on the commercial imperatives of the organisation rather than on the overwhelming responsibility that was cast upon them to ensure that the air travelling public in Australia was safe.

I agree with the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) who spoke a while ago with regard to the focus being on the bottom end of the market, as it were, or on general aviation, and that there is a responsibility for the other 40 million travelling public. But this incident happened in the middle with RPT/charter operators that were working at the margin, I suppose. Maybe, the financial viability of their organisations was questionable but, just the same, as I said before, the people that bought tickets to travel on this aircraft to Lord Howe Island were entitled to the same expectation of safety as the person buying a ticket on 747‐400 of Qantas to travel overseas. As a government we have a responsibility to ensure that in the future such accidents do not happen.

I had the opportunity of having a briefing yesterday from CASA staff, and there is no doubt that there is an enormous change in attitude following our recommendation of the JCPA that the responsibilities and activities of air traffic control be separated from safety regulation. Subsequently, the government of the day created Airservices Australia which is a corporate entity running as a business, controlling air traffic in our skies, and bringing safety regulations and safety surveillance back in as an agency to surveil the safety operations in the aviation sector in Australia.

I certainly was heartened yesterday to be briefed by CASA on what they are doing, how they are going to operate and the new focus of the organisation. We note the recommendations of the Plane Safe report of the former Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, chaired by the member for Shortland, in the last parliament. Those recommendations have been taken up by the government. The now minister was a member of that committee in the last parliament. He participated in the complete inquiry that resulted in the Plane Safe report. So there is a commitment throughout this parliament to improve the regulation of the safety aspects of aviation in Australia today. I commend that to all members because it is of paramount importance.

The other issue that has been referred to here this morning is the tension that apparently exists between the minister and some members of the board of CASA. That is, I think, a result of some differences of opinion as to what sorts of expertise should exist on that board—for example, the question of whether direct aviation experience is necessary on that board. A lot of us believe that it is, but that is one issue—previous speakers have alluded to the fact that it may or may not be having an impact on morale within CASA. I am sure it will sort itself out but the main object of the exercise at the moment for the government, for the department and for CASA is to improve immeasurably on what has happened in the past but certainly to restructure the organisation and the focus of the organisation so that they realise and they are committed to what they are there for.

After the briefing that we received yesterday, I am sure that that is going to occur. There is a commitment by the minister to ensure that that happens and to ensure that when we buy a ticket to travel on an aircraft somewhere we can do that in the complete confidence that we are travelling very safely, unlike the case in a lot of other countries in the world.

With the dramatic increase in the amount of air travel around the world, the responsibilities incumbent on CASA are not only to surveil aircraft that originate out of this country but also to surveil aircraft that travel into and out of Australia—foreign carriers—which, from time to time, carry Australian nationals. Those aircraft, as we have seen, can certainly make a big hole in the ground and they can be very dangerous. There was a recent incident in New Delhi and neither of those aircraft were Indian national aircraft, they were foreign carriers but they were operating in that country and carrying some of their nationals.

So there is a responsibility, and a growing responsibility, on CASA to surveil aircraft that are operating in and out of Australia because, from time to time, we do travel with those airlines. There is a growing concern in that area. CASA are aware of it and are implementing measures to do that. As a parliament and certainly as a government, we are going to support CASA. I know the minister is supporting them with the new regime they are implementing with regard to the management of CASA, particularly as a result of those tragedies, originally with Monarch and, more importantly today, with the inquiry of the royal commission that was conducted into the tragedy of that Seaview flight.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend Commissioner Staunton on the work he has done in this report and I am sure that all members are cognisant of what needs to be achieved in the future after the tragedy of the Seaview air crash.
Debate (on motion by Mr Grace) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will small businesses that reach stipulated asset, turnover and employment levels be required to engage professional auditors after 30 June 1996; if so, (a) will the requirement apply if the shareholders of a business are also its managers, (b) on what basis will affected businesses be deemed large, (c) will the relevant books of account for 1995‐96 also be required to be audited to avoid otherwise inevitable qualifications being attached by auditors to final accounts for 1996‐97, (d) what is the estimated average cost of compliance to affected businesses and (e) what implications does the requirement have for the Government's stated intention to reduce the regulation and compliance costs of small businesses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A proprietary company will be classified as a large proprietary company, and thus be required to have its accounts audited under the Corporations Law, where it and the entities that it controls meet 2 of the following criteria:

PARA.TAB: consolidated gross operating revenue of $10 million or more;
consolidated gross assets of $5 million or more; or
50 or more employees at the end of the financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: Answers to the specific matters raised in the question are:

(a) Each large proprietary company that was formerly classified as an exempt proprietary company will be required to have its accounts audited for the first financial year of the company that commences after 9 December 1995. This requirement will apply irrespective of whether a company's shareholders are directors of the company or are otherwise engaged in the management of the company. Companies meeting the large proprietary company test are significant enterprises and generally have a number of creditors or members with an interest in the company's accounts.

The Corporations Law does, however, provide that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) may relieve a large proprietary company of the obligation to have its accounts audited where the audit would impose an unreasonable burden on the company. In considering whether to provide such relief, the ASC must have regard to, inter alia, the expected costs of complying with the audit requirements and the expected benefits of having the company comply with those requirements.

On 19 November 1996 the ASC released its audit relief policy for large proprietary companies (Policy Statement Number 115). The audit relief policy permits large proprietary companies that have not been audited since 1993:

PARA.TAB: to continue to prepare and lodge unaudited accounts for the first financial year commencing after 9 December 1995; and

to apply for ongoing relief from the requirement to be audited for the second financial year commencing after 9 December 1995, where they can satisfy criteria demonstrating that they are well managed and in sound financial position.

ANSWER.PARA: A small proprietary company will not be required to appoint an auditor unless:

PARA.TAB: it is a disclosing entity as defined in the Corporations Law; or
it is controlled by a foreign company and its profit or loss for the period is not included in the foreign company's accounts; or
it is subject to a shareholder request to prepare audited accounts; or
it is required by the ASC to lodge audited accounts.

ANSWER.PARA: (b) See introductory comments.

(c) I am advised that the question whether the accounts for 1995‐96 will have to be audited to avoid having the accounts for 1996‐97 qualified will be a matter for consideration by each company and its auditor. An auditor, in forming a view on this matter, would be guided by his or her professional judgement. The final decision would be based on a consideration of issues such as the level of reliance that can be placed on the accounting records.

(d) I am advised that no Treasury or Australian Securities Commission estimate of the average cost of compliance with the audit requirements is available. I would expect the audit fee to be determined by factors such as the form in which the accounting records are maintained and the adequacy of those records, the nature and adequacy of the company's internal controls, the number of transactions and the geographical spread of the company's operations.

(e) The Government remains firmly committed to reducing the regulation and compliance costs for all levels of business. The small/large test for proprietary companies will be reviewed after 2 years operation of the legislation to ensure that its practical operation does not place an undue burden on business.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What instructions, orally or in writing, has the Minister given to the Secretary of the Minister's Department to cancel, modify, alter, diminish, suspend or suspend funding for, employment or labour market programs under the Minister's control.

(2) Does the Minister or the Minister's Department employ Mr Sandy Hollway; if so, (a) in what capacity and (b) has Mr Hollway received any instructions from the Minister or any other Minister, including but not limited to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, to cancel, modify, alter, diminish, suspend or suspend funding for, employment or labour market programs administered by the Minister's Department.

(3) Has the Minister attended a committee meeting, conference, seminar, discussion or consultation where the cancellation, modification, suspension, alteration or suspension of funding for, employment or labour market programs administered by the minister's Department was discussed, mentioned, explored or referred to; if so, in each case, (a) when, (b) where, (c) who attended, (d) in what capacity did they attend and (e) what current or future action was decided upon as a result.

(4) What instructions, orally or in writing, have been given to or received by any (a) deputy secretary, (b) person employed by the Employment Programs Delivery Division, (c) manager of any office of the Commonwealth Employment Service or (d) employee of the Minister's Department that have the effect of cancelling, modifying, altering, diminishing, suspending or suspending funding for, employment or labour market programs under the Minister's control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Secretary and I discussed the rate of spending on labour market programs, in particular the possibility of expenditure exceeding the amount of funds appropriated a number of times during March, April and May. I agreed with the Secretary that, given the overall Budgetary situation, the Department should manage within the Appropriation.
(2) Yes
(a) Mr Sandy Hollway is Secretary of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
(b) No, not in 1995‐96.

(3) and (4) I met with Mr Hollway and other officers in the Department to discuss how to manage within the Appropriation. Given the high rate of commitment and expenditure prior to the March election the Government decided on 17 April 1996 to bring forward $30m from the 1996‐97 forward estimates.
Mr Hollway, on 9 May 1996 issued a minute to all Area Managers giving instructions on management of labour market program funding for the remainder of 1995‐96. That minute was tabled in both Houses.

Subsequently it was found that commitments were still very high and the Government approved a further bring forward of $39.6m (i.e. a total bring forward of $69.6m). As a result while the previous Government's 1995‐96 Labour Market program allocation at the time of the election was $2087.0m, final expenditure was $2156.6m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Conference on Education for All

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 15 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the World Conference on Education for All in Jomtien, Thailand, in March 1990 produced a plan to eradicate illiteracy by the year 2000.

(2) Is he also able to say whether the Conference was sponsored and attended by the President of the World Bank Group, the Executive Director of UNICEF, the Administrator of the United Nations Development Program and the Director‐General of UNESCO.
(3) Was Australia an associate sponsor of the Conference and did Australia send a delegation to the Conference.

(4) Is he able to say whether the Director‐General of UNESCO, the President of the World Bank Group, the Administrator of the United Nations Development Fund and the Executive Directors of UNICEF and the United Nations Population Fund organised an International Consultative Forum on Education for All in Amman, Jordan, in June 1996 to review the plan; if so, was the Forum attended by 250 participants from 73 countries, including 17 in the Asia‐Pacific region.
(5) Were there Australian participants at the Forum; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The World Conference on Education for All in Jomtien, Thailand in March 1990 did not produce a plan to eradicate literacy by the year 2000. However, it did produce a World Declaration on Education for All and a Framework for Action to Meet Basic Learning Needs. Paragraph 8(4) of the Framework suggests a target in relation to the reduction in adult illiteracy.
The World Plan to Eradicate Illiteracy by the Year 2000 was produced by UNESCO before the Jomtien Conference.

(2) Yes, the Conference was sponsored and attended by the President of the World Bank Group, the Executive Director of UNICEF, the Administrator of the United Nations Development Program and the Director‐General of UNESCO.
(3) Yes, Australia was an associate sponsor and did send a delegation.

(4) The Director‐General of UNESCO, the President of the World Bank Group, the Administrator of the United Nations Development Fund and the Executive Director of UNICEF organised an International Consultative Forum on Education for All in Amman. The Executive Director of the United Nations Population Fund was not an organiser of the Conference, but did attend.

The figures for participation at the Forum meeting are correct. However, the 250 participants were from, but not representing, 73 countries. The Amman Forum meeting was not an inter‐governmental meeting nor was it intended to be fully geographically representative. Participants from a cross‐section of countries were invited in their personal capacity; some were government officials, but many were from outside government.

(5) The International Consultative Forum did not invite any Australians to participate in the meeting. However, Dr Colin Power, an Australian, in his independent capacity as Assistant‐Director General for Education, UNESCO, did attend the meeting. While Australia was not invited to attend the Amman Conference, Australia did provide the International Consultative Forum with a country report for the Mid‐Decade Review of Progress towards Education for All. A global report on the Mid‐Term Review based on the analysis of country reports was presented to the Amman Conference and formed the basis for discussion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 17 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister release the report of the SkillShare Services Review Committee; if so, when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Certain Family Law Issues Committee: Recommendation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues recommended that research be undertaken into the costs of children in Australia.

(2) Has research into the matter referred to in part (1) been commissioned by the Minister's Department; if so, (a) what methodologies are available to determine the costs of children, (b) did the Minister's Department assess methodologies; if so, what was its assessment, (c) what methodology was selected, (d) what were the terms of reference for the research, (e) who will conduct the research, (f) how long will the study take and (g) what will the study cost.
(3) Is the Minister able to say whether the results of the study will be used by the (a) Child Support Agency and (b) the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Recommendation 116 of the Report on the Child Support Scheme by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues recommended that "the Minister for Social Security commissions an independent study into the costs of children to enable a critical evaluation of the current child support formula percentages".
(2) In response to this recommendation research was commissioned by the Department of Social Security in 1995.

(2)(a) A number of approaches are possible for determining the costs of children. These usually involve either the analysis of survey data on the expenditure patterns of families, or the costing of a basket of goods and services which are considered necessary for raising children.

(2)(b) and (c) The Department of Social Security considered that a comprehensive basket of goods and services approach which also took account of the actual expenditure patterns of families would overcome the limitations of costs of children methodologies previously used in Australia. This approach is commonly known as the "Budget Standards" methodology. It has been used in other countries over recent times for research purposes including determining the costs of children.

(2)(d) The costs of children research is being undertaken as part of a larger research project to develop indicative Budget Standards for a range of different household configurations, including families with children in a variety of employment and housing circumstances. The contract involves:

PARA.TAB: research and consultation with a range of experts and academics into what it is to have an adequate level of health, housing, nutrition etc. and what goods and services are required to achieve this;

research into the actual costs of the goods and services consumed by household members, including children. These goods and services include housing, food, clothing, energy use, household goods and services, personal care, leisure goods and services;

analysis of the actual expenditure patterns of Australian households through detailed examination of existing research and data such as the Australian Bureau of Statistics Household Expenditure Survey; and
"reality checking" assumptions and Budget Standards data against feedback from a series of focus groups comprised of members of particular household types, including families with children.

ANSWER.PARA: Particular issues relating to the costs of children that are specifically required to be addressed include: economies of scale for households with varying numbers of adults and children; costs of children according to their age and position in the household; and the particular costs to a parent of having regular contact with a child where that child does not live in the same household as the parent.
(2)(e) The Budget Standards research is being carried out by the Social Policy Research Centre (Budget Standards Unit) at the University of New South Wales.
(2)(f) The contract allows 104 weeks for completion of the research (the research commenced in October 1995).
(2)(g) The research on the costs of children is an integral part of the overall Budget Standards research which will cost around $630,000.

(3) When the results of the research are available I will ask the Department of Social Security to assess their usefulness for critically evaluating the percentages in the current child support formula. I will also consult my colleagues, the Assistant Treasurer and the Attorney‐General about how the results might be used for child support purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Price

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Child Support Agency make submissions to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues; if so, did a submission and evidence refer to the exempt or disregarded income of the then non‐custodial parent and the living allowance of the then non‐custodial parent; if so, what was stated.
(2) Are the two concepts referred to in part (1) different.
(3) Is there a legislative basis for a distinction between the two concepts; if not, why does his Department use differing terminology.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Child Support Agency made two submissions to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. The first referred to the non‐custodial parent's `exempted income amount' at various points. It also referred to the non‐custodial parent's `self support component' at various points. At page 124 it said, "(the current legislation sets two income figures which could be said to represent the concept of self support. There is a basic amount used in the assessment (self support exemption called the exempted income amount) and there is a second amount when it comes to collection from an employee's pay (the protected earnings amount))."

`Exempted income amount' appeared in a glossary of terms, and was defined as "that part of the non‐custodial parent's taxable income which is not taken into account in assessing child support, that is, the single pension rate if there are no other children or the married pension rate plus an allowance for each child if there are other dependent children." `Self support component' did not appear in this glossary.
(2) No, the `exempted income amount' and the `self support component' are not different concepts, but different ways of expressing the same concept.

(3) The Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 uses the term `exempted income amount', with its meaning given by section 39. `Self support component' was used by the Agency as an alternative to simplify the child support assessment formula. The Agency no longer tends to use the term `self support component'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Review Office the means by which clients of the Child Support Agency (CSA) have decisions of the CSA reviewed; if so, do officers of the Review Office follow precedents in conducting reviews.
(2) Are decisions of the review officers published.
(3) Is the only avenue of appeal against decisions of review officers to the Family Court of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Child Support Review Office provides an administrative method for departing from administrative assessments raised under Child Support legislation. The Child Support Review Office does not review other decisions of the Child Support Agency. Clients of the Child Support Agency have the right to object against some decisions made under the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and appeal rights are to the Family Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Review officers follow and are bound by Family Court precedents.
(2) Decisions of review officers are not published, however the parties are notified in writing of the reasons for the determination.

(3) Section 115 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 provides the circumstances under which an application can be made to the Family Court of Australia after a determination has been made by a review officer. It is not an appeal from the determination made by the review officer. The court deals with the matter as if it were an initial application.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Club TAB and Keno Income: Taxation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Deputy Commissioner for Taxation in NSW made a determination that commissions received by registered clubs in NSW from TAB and Keno operations conducted within clubs are now taxable; if so, (a) when and (b) why was the determination made.
(2) Has the Deputy Commissioner also determined that the tax is payable retrospectively for five years; if so, why.
(3) What is the estimated total revenue to be collected from this tax (a) for the five year retrospective period, (b) annually and (c) from licensed clubs in the electoral division of Barton.
(4) Does he support these actions having regard to a commitment by the Coalition during the last federal election campaign that there would be no new taxes in the life of this Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) A letter was sent to a representative of the Registered Clubs Association (RCA) of NSW on 3 October 1996 advising (on a without prejudice basis) that Keno commission income derived by registered clubs is assessable income and is not subject to the principle of mutuality. The letter did not deal with commission income from TAB operations.

(b) The issue of the taxation treatment of Keno commission income arose during contact with a taxpayer during August 1996. Further investigation revealed that many clubs had assumed that the commission income was subject to the principle of mutuality and therefore not assessable income.
The principle of mutuality is, broadly, based upon the proposition that a taxpayer cannot derive
income from itself. Generally, under this proposition, income derived by registered clubs from their members is not treated as assessable income for taxation purposes.

However, Keno commissions are paid to clubs by Club Keno Holdings Pty Ltd and are not derived from club members. Under the same principle, commissions paid to clubs by the TAB are assessable income, not tax exempt mutual income.

In view of the widespread misunderstanding of the tax status of the commission income, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is attempting to resolve this matter in close consultation with the registered club industry.

(2) No. The ATO has not determined the tax liability of clubs at this time. It is true that Keno has been operating in NSW since September 1991, but as already noted, the ATO is negotiating with the registered club industry to resolve the matter.

(3)(a) and (b) No estimates of revenue collections for tax on Keno commission income have been made for the five year period or on an annual basis. However, the following gross commission income was derived by licensed clubs in NSW from Keno operations as shown in the following table:

These figures represent gross commission amounts only and there may be tax deductible expenses related to the derivation of this income. In addition, a number of clubs deriving Keno commission income are exempt from income tax and revenue collections will, therefore, be reduced accordingly. Further, a proportion of the income may already have been returned by non‐exempt clubs as part of their income derived from non‐members.
(c) No details are available for estimated revenue collections for licensed clubs deriving Keno commission income in the electoral division of Barton.

(4) The taxation treatment of Keno and TAB commission income is being determined under existing taxation law. Registered clubs have incorrectly assumed that the commission income is exempt when it has always been taxable under the law. Clearly no new `tax' is involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What sum has the Minister's Department spent on the purchase of paper products since 1 April 1996, and what proportion of those purchases was Australian made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department has spent $102,494 on sheet paper since 1 July 1996. It is not cost effective to provide further detailed breakup of costings for the timeframe specified. However, the Department's sheet paper and envelopes supplies, as well as other paper product stationery stores, are all purchased under the Buyers Guide provisions. These provi‐ sions laid down by the Department of Administrative Services stipulate the purchase of Australian and New Zealand products. The Department is unable to identify the point of origin of paper products contained in books and periodicals purchased by the Department. Any further issues regarding the point of origin of specific paper products covered under the Buyers Guide should be more appropriately directed to the Minister for Administrative Services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: When and for what purposes has the Employment Committee of Cabinet met since its establishment and the date of preparation of the answer to this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Consistent with longstanding practice, I am not prepared to disclose the details of meetings of the Cabinet or its Committees.
